We're differentiating with respect to x, so why is it that you differentiate with respect to y for the outside function (of the composite function)  Edit: Ooh, I got it. You're applying the chain rule, just like how you'll use the chain rule to solve any other function.  And the reason why it's in respect to y for the outside function is that the way you differentiate a composite function is to first difference the outside one with respect to the inside function. Multiply that with the derivative of the inner function with respect to its variable. For y^2, the inner function is y. So since the chain rule differentiates the outside function with respect to the inner one, the outside function (Y^2) will be differentiated with respect to y (the inner function.) Then multiply with the derivative of y respect to the variable it's representing. Y, is representing a function (something happening to x) its not a variable itself in this instance, so the variable within the function of y is x, that's why the inner one differentiated with respect to x again.

Is it possible that the second solution is wrong?  y' = (5y - 2x) / (6y -5x)  instead of  y' = (2x - 5y) / (5x - 6y) 2x -5(xy' + y) + 6yy' = 0 2x -5xy' -5y + 6yy' = 0 6yy' -5xy' = 5y - 2x y'(6y - 5x) = 5y - 2x y' = (5y - 2x) / (6y -5x)

Had a hard time wrapping my head around the d/dx, d/dy, dy/dx notations. Here is how it made sense to me:  x^2 + y^2 = 0 d(x^2)/dx + d(y^2)/dx = 0  d(x^2)/dx is the same as (x^2)' from the previous lectures, so that is 2x 2x + d(y^2)/dx = 0  d(y^2)/dx is tricky because the differential function is not divided by "dy" what we learned before was d(y^2)/dy = 2y  this can be expressed as d(y^2) = 2y*dy  plugging that into the last equation: 2x +  2y*dy/dx = 0  dy/dx = y', so 2x + 2y.y' = 0

Hi! The raw answer is y'= (-2x+5y)/(-5x+6y) but professor here likes to keep all in positive terms, it's cleaner he says. So he multiplies up and bottom by -1/-1 and then you get y'= (2x-5y)/(5x-6y).   I hoped I helped you.

Yeah you can learn from an 11 minute video. Although keep in mind, you can also pause the video and re-watch parts that did not make sense the first time around. Lectures from math professors cover more than how to do problems. They cover the reasons why more in depth. Let F(x,y)=x^2+y^2-9.  Then, dy/dx=-F_x/F_y=-2x/2y=-x/y.  Here F_x is the partial derivative of F with respect to x.

the first example there is just one term, but it's a composite function so it needs the chain rule. for the other one it's a product so we need the product rule, and for one of the terms in the product we also need the chain rule.

How did it go
well you're looking at one right now.
F(x,y)=x^3+x^2y+4y^2-6.  dy/dx=-f_x/F_y=-(3x^2+2xy)/(x^2+8y)=[-x(3x+2y)]/(x^2+8y)  would be nice if they implemented LaTeX to the comments section
this is just an application of the multivariate chain rule
This is definitely an easier way to differentiate that function! Its multivariable calculus but its not hard, a partial derivative is just treating the other variable like a constant.
